definitions.text: I also, I too, but I.
(a) I take down, pull down, depose, destroy.
I lay hold of, fasten on to
I lay hold of, fasten on to, seize, attack.

I cleanse, make clean, literally, ceremonially, or spiritually,
                  according to context.

cleansing, purifying, purification, literal, ceremonial, or moral; met:
                  expiation.

clean, pure, unstained, either literally or ceremonially or
                  spiritually; guiltless, innocent, upright.
I am sitting, sit, am seated
I am sitting, sit down, am seated.

in order, in succession, in the time immediately after, just
                  after.
I come down, come to; I am unfit, proper.
I sit, am seated, enthroned; I dwell, reside.

(a) trans: I make to sit; I set, appoint, (b) intrans: I sit down, am
                  seated, stay.

I set down, bring down to a place; I set in order, appoint, make,
                  constitute.
according to which thing, as, according as.
one the whole, in general, altogether.
(a) in proportion as, according as, (b) because.

according to the manner in which, in the degree that, just as,
                  as.
(Hebrew), Cain, son of Adam and Eve and brother of Abel.
(Hebrew), Cainan, one of the ancestors of Jesus.
fitting season, season, opportunity, occasion, time.

Caesar, a surname of the gens Iulia, which became practically
                  synonymous with the Emperor for the time being; in the Gospels it always refers to
                  Tiberias.

Two cities of Palestine: one in Galilee (Caesarea Philippi), the other
                  on the coast of the Mediterranean.
I ignite, light, burn, lit. and met; I consume with fire.
and there, and yonder, there also.
and thence, and from there; and then afterwards.
and he, she, it, and that
and he, she, it, and that.

(a) evil (i.e. trouble, labor, misfortune), (b) wickedness, (c) vicious
                  disposition, malice, spite.
I speak evil of, curse, revile, abuse.

experience of evil, suffering, distress, affliction,
                  perseverance.
I do harm, do wrong, do evil, commit sin.
bad, evil, in the widest sense.
I treat badly, afflict, embitter, make angry.
a reed; a reed-pen, reed-staff, measuring rod.
(a) I call, summon, invite, (b) I call, name.
a teacher of that which is noble
a teacher of that which is noble (honorable) and good.
I do well, act honorably, do what is right.

beautiful, as an outward sign of the inward good, noble, honorable
                  character; good, worthy, honorable, noble, and seen to be so.
a covering, especially a covering of head and face, a veil.
I work, am weary, am sick.
and if, even if, even, at least.

Candace, a proper name; the Candace, a dynastic name for queens of the
                  Ethiopians in Abyssinia.

(lit: a level, ruler), a rule, regulation, rule of conduct or doctrine,
                  (b) a measured (defined) area, province.
I hawk, trade in, deal in for purposes of gain.

Cappadocia, a large Roman province in the central eastern part of Asia
                  Minor.

lit: the heart; mind, character, inner self, will, intention,
                  center.
a knower of the inner life
a knower of the inner life (character, hearts).

(a) fruit, generally vegetable, sometimes animal, (b) met: fruit, deed,
                  action, result, (c) profit, gain.
I persevere, endure, am steadfast, patient.
a dry stalk, chip of wood
a dry stalk, chip of wood, twig, splinter, chaff.
down from, against, according to, throughout, during

gen: against, down from, throughout, by; acc: over against, among,
                  daily, day-by-day, each day, according to, by way of.

I go down, come down, either from the sky or from higher land,
                  descend.
(a) mid: I lay, of a foundation, (b) met: I cast down, prostrate.
I bring down, cause to go down
I bring down, cast down, cause to go down.

(a) foundation, (b) depositing, sowing, deposit, technically used of
                  the act of conception.

of the umpire in a contest: I decide against, take part against,
                  condemn (perhaps with the idea of assumption, officialism).
I declare openly, proclaim, preach, laud, celebrate.
I break down (in pieces), crush, break into.

I lead down, bring down, either from a high place on land or to a lower
                  (or actually to the sea-coast), or from the high seas to land.
I subdue (in warfare); I struggle against, conquer, overcome.
I shame, disgrace, put to utter confusion

I shame, disgrace, bring to shame, put to utter confusion,
                  frustrate.

I recline (at table); more often: I keep my bed, am lying ill (in
                  bed).
I break in pieces, break up.
I give as an inheritance, distribute by lot.
I cause to recline at table; mid. and pass: I recline at table.
I cut up, cut in pieces, mangle, wound.
I cast down headlong, throw over a precipice.
punishment following condemnation, penal servitude, penalty.
I condemn, judge worthy of punishment.
I exercise authority over, overpower, master.
I speak evil of, rail at, slander.
slanderous, back-biting; subst: a railer, defamer.
I seize tight hold of, overtake, comprehend

(a) I seize tight hold of, arrest, catch, capture, appropriate, (b) I
                  overtake, (c) mid. aor: I perceived, comprehended.
I enter in a list, register
I enter in a list, register, enroll.

I leave behind, desert, abandon, forsake; I leave remaining,
                  reserve.
I stone down, stone to death
I stone down, stone to death, overwhelm with stones.
left behind; the rest, the remainder.
I break up, overthrow, unharness, find a lodging
I understand, take in a fact about, consider carefully.
I wait, stay (with), remain, abide, dwell.
I use up, spend, consume (as with fire).
(properly a medical term: I stupefy, hence) I burden, encumber.
I nod, make a sign, beckon.

I take note of, perceive, consider carefully, discern, detect, make
                  account of.
I come down, arrive at, reach

(a) I come down, either from high land to lower (or actually to the
                  sea-coast), or from the high seas to the coast; hence met: I arrive at, reach (my
                  destination), (b) of property: I come down (descend) by inheritance to an
                  heir.
met: I am pierced, stung, smitten.
I trample down, trample under foot (lit. and met.), spurn.

(in the Old Testament of the rest attained by the settlement in
                  Canaan), resting, rest, dwelling, habitation.

(a) trans: I cause to rest, bring to rest; I cause to refrain, (b)
                  intrans: I rest.

(lit: that which is spread out downwards, that which hangs down), a
                  curtain, veil, of that which separated the Holy of Holies from the outer parts of
                  the temple at Jerusalem, also of an outer curtain at the entrance to the Holy
                  Place in the same temple.
I drink down, swallow, devour, destroy, consume.
I sail down (from the high seas to the shore).
I exhaust by labor or suffering, wear out, overpower, oppress.
I sink in the sea, am drowned
I sink in the sea, pass: I drown, am submerged.
cursing; a curse; meton: a doomed one.
I bring to naught, sever, abolish

(a) I make idle (inactive), make of no effect, annul, abolish, bring to
                  naught, (b) I discharge, sever, separate from.

(a) I fit (join) together; met: I compact together, (b) act. and mid: I
                  prepare, perfect, for his (its) full destination or use, bring into its proper
                  condition (whether for the first time, or after a lapse).
a bringing to a condition of fitness, perfecting.

I shake (the hand) up and down, wave; intrans: I beckon for
                  silence.
I dig down under, demolish, undermine.
I build, construct, prepare, make ready.
I encamp, take up my quarters, tabernacle, pitch my tent, dwell.
I view closely, inspect, spy out.
I let down, lower; I keep down, restrain, pacify.
I strew or spread over; I lay low, overthrow.
I seal up, secure with a seal.

(a) I lay down, deposit, (b) mid: I lay down or deposit a favor, with
                  the view of receiving one in return, seek favor.
I bear down, overpower; I give a vote or verdict, bring charges.

I flee for refuge (implying that the refuge is reached); aor. indicates
                  moment of arrival.
I despise, scorn, and show it by active insult, disregard.
I use to the full, use up.
full of images of idols, grossly idolatrous.
before the face of, over against.
I effect by labor, achieve, work out, bring about.

I come down from sky to earth, or from high land to lower land (or to
                  the coast), or from the high seas to the shore.
I eat till it is finished

I eat up, eat till it is finished, devour, squander, annoy,
                  injure.
(a) I make straight, (b) met: I put in the right way, direct.
I rush, assault, rise up against.

(a) I hold fast, bind, arrest, (b) I take possession of, lay hold of,
                  (c) I hold back, detain, restrain, (d) I hold a ship, keep its head.

a downcast countenance as a sign of sorrow, gloominess, gloom,
                  dejection.
I rust; pass: I am rusted, tarnished.
I prevail against, overpower, am able
I prevail against, overpower, get the upper hand.
I dwell in, settle in, inhabit
I dwell in, settle in, am established in (permanently), inhabit.

anything happily and successfully accomplished, a beneficial and worthy
                  deed.

(a) down, below, also: downwards, (b) lower, under, less, of a length
                  of time.
I cauterize, burn with a hot iron; hence met: I sear.
a boasting; a ground of boasting (glorying, exultation).
the act of boasting, glorying, exultation.
Cenchreae, the port of Corinth on the Saronic Gulf.

I lie, recline, am placed, am laid, set, specially appointed,
                  destined.
a kind of girdle made of cords; a bandage, grave clothes.
I shear, cut the hair of

I shear, cut the hair of; mid: I cut my own hair, have my hair
                  cut.
a word of command, a call
a word of command, a call, an arousing outcry.

(a) empty, (b) met: empty (in moral content), vain, ineffective,
                  foolish, worthless, (c) false, unreal, pretentious, hollow.
I empty, deprive of content, make unreal
(a) I empty, (b) I deprive of content, make unreal.
a sting, goad; met: of death.

a centurion, an officer commanding about a hundred infantry in the
                  Roman army.
falsely, in vain, to no purpose.

a little hook, an apostrophe on letters of the alphabet, distinguishing
                  them from other little letters, or a separation stroke between letters.
of clay, made by a potter
of clay, made by a potter, earthen.
I mix, pour out for drinking
I mix, mingle, pour out for drinking.

(a) a horn, (b) a horn-like projection at the corner of an altar, (c) a
                  horn as a symbol of power.
I gain, acquire, win (over), avoid loss.
a small coin; plur: small change.
properly: a changer of large into smaller coins, a money-changer.
the chief matter, a sum of money
(a) the chief matter, the main point, (b) a sum of money.

(a) the head, (b) met: a corner stone, uniting two walls; head, ruler,
                  lord.

(lit: little head, then: the knob at the end of the wooden core of a
                  roll of papyrus, then) a roll, volume, division (of a book).
a garden, any place planted with trees and herbs.
a sea monster, huge sea fish, whale.

Cephas (Aramaic for rock), the new name given to Simon Peter, the
                  apostle.

(properly: a wooden box, hence) the Ark, in which Noah sailed; the Ark
                  of the Covenant.

intrans. and trans: I play on the harp, I harp, with acc. of the
                  tune.
a harpist, one who sings with harp as accompaniment.

Cilicia, a Roman province between the Taurus range of mountains and the
                  coast in the south-east corner of Asia Minor, linked up with the province of
                  Syria.
I am in danger or peril.
I set in motion, move, remove, excite, stir up.
a young tender shoot, then: a branch; met: of descendants.
I weep, weep for, mourn, lament.

Cauda, Clauda, an island twenty-three miles south of the western end of
                  Crete.

Claudia, a Christian woman in Rome; probably a freedwoman of the
                  imperial household.

(a) Claudius, the fourth of the Roman Emperors, Tiberius Claudius
                  Caesar Augustus Germanicus, who ruled A.D. 41-54, (b) Claudius Lysias, a tribune
                  at Jerusalem.

Cleopas, one of the two companions of the risen Jesus from Jerusalem to
                  Emmaus.
glory, fame, praise; rumor, report, credit.
Clement, a fellow-worker of Paul in Rome.
I inherit, obtain (possess) by inheritance, acquire.

an inheritance, an heritage, regularly the gift of God to His chosen
                  people, in the Old Testament: the Promised Land, in NT a possession viewed in one
                  sense as present, in another as future; a share, participation.

(a) a lot, (b) a portion assigned; hence: a portion of the people of
                  God assigned to one's care, a congregation.

I cast lots, choose by lot, assign by lot, assign a portion, receive a
                  share.
a calling, invitation; in the NT, always of a divine call.
called, invited, summoned by God to an office or to salvation.
a small geographical division, district, or territory.

a couch, bed, portable bed or mat, a couch for reclining at meals,
                  possibly also a bier.
a couch or litter of a sick person.
I rest, recline, make to yield

trans: I rest, recline; I bend, incline; I cause to give ground, make
                  to yield; intrans: I decline, approach my end.
a dining couch, group of diners
properly: a dining couch; hence: a group of diners.
rough water, a wave, billow, surge.
I am tossed by waves, met: I am tossed to and fro.
Clopas, husband of one Mary, who stood by the cross.
I rub, tickle, scratch; pass: I itch.

Cnidus, a town on the coast of Caria (south-west Asia Minor) near the
                  island of Cos.

a "quadrans," the smallest Roman copper coin, a quarter of an "as," the
                  sixteenth part of a "sesterius".

belly, abdomen, heart, a general term covering any organ in the
                  abdomen, e.g. stomach, womb; met: the inner man.
I fall asleep, am asleep, sometimes of the sleep of death.

(a) common, shared, (b) Hebraistic use: profane; dirty, unclean,
                  unwashed.
I make unclean, regard as unclean

I make unclean, pollute, desecrate, mid: I regard (treat) as
                  unclean.
I share, communicate, have fellowship with

(a) I share, communicate, contribute, impart, (b) I share in, have a
                  share of, have fellowship with.

(lit: partnership) (a) contributory help, participation, (b) sharing
                  in, communion, (c) spiritual fellowship, a fellowship in the spirit.
willing to share, sociable, ready to communicate, beneficent.

(a) a bed, (b) a marriage bed; plur: repeated (immoral) sexual
                  intercourse.

crimson, scarlet, dyed with Kermes (coccum), the female coccus of the
                  Kermes oak.
I chastise, curtail, punish; mid: I cause to be punished.
flattery, with a view to advantage or gain.

chastisement, punishment, torment, perhaps with the idea of
                  deprivation.
I strike with the fist, maltreat
I strike with the fist, buffet; hence: I mistreat violently.
I glue, cleave, keep company with

(lit: I glue); hence: mid. and pass: I join myself closely, cleave,
                  adhere (to), I keep company (with), of friendly intercourse.

a money-changer, who changed heathen into Jewish money, for payment
                  into the Temple treasury.
(lit: I maim, mutilate), I cut short, shorten, abbreviate.

Colossae, a town of the Roman province Asia, in the Lycus valley, near
                  Laodicea and Hierapolis.
bosom, bosom of a garment, a bay, gulf

(a) sing. and plur: bosom; (sinus) the overhanging fold of the garment
                  used as a pocket, (b) a bay, gulf.
(lit: a diving or swimming place), a pool.

a colony, a city settlement of Roman (soldier) citizens; a garrison
                  city.
I wear the hair long, allow the hair to grow out.

(a) act: I convey, bring, carry, (b) mid: I receive back, receive what
                  has belonged to myself but has been lost, or else promised but kept back, or: I
                  get what has come to be my own by earning, recover.
I abate, cease raging, am stilled.
beating of the breast or head in lamentation, lamentation.

(a) I grow weary, (b) I toil, work with effort (of bodily and mental
                  labor alike).

(a) trouble, (b) toil, labor, laborious toil, involving weariness and
                  fatigue.

(a) I cut, cut off, strike, smite, (b) mid: I beat my breast or head in
                  lamentation, lament, mourn, sometimes with acc. of person whose loss is
                  mourned.
a little girl, a young girl; a girl, maiden.
a gift, offering, anything consecrated to God.
I fill, sate, glut, feed full, satisfy.

Corinth, in north-east Peloponnese, the capital of the Roman province
                  Achaia.
Cornelius, a centurion of the Roman army, stationed at Caesarea.
I put into order; I decorate, deck, adorn.

earthly, worldly (belonging to the present earthly world as opposed to
                  the heavenly and future).

ruler of this world, that is, of the world as asserting its
                  independence of God; used of the angelic or demonic powers controlling the
                  sublunary world.

the world, universe; worldly affairs; the inhabitants of the world;
                  adornment.
Quartus, a Christian, brother of Erastus the Corinthian.
a bed, mattress, mat of a poor man.
I strengthen, confirm; pass: I grow strong, become strong.

I am strong, mighty, hence: I rule, am master, prevail; I obtain, take
                  hold of; I hold, hold fast.

most excellent, an official epithet, used in addressing a Roman of high
                  rank, and in the second century one of equestrian (as distinguished from
                  senatorial) rank.
dominion, strength, power; a mighty deed.
(a) a shout, cry, clamor, (b) outcry, clamoring against another.
flesh; plur: pieces of flesh, kinds of flesh.
I hang, hang up, suspend; mid: I am hanging, hang.
a Cretan, an inhabitant of Crete.
Crescens, a Christian, coadjutor of Paul.

(a) a judgment, a verdict; sometimes implying an adverse verdict, a
                  condemnation, (b) a case at law, a lawsuit.

a lily growing wild, variously identified with the red anemone, the
                  whole lily, the sword lily.

(a) I judge, whether in a law-court or privately: sometimes with
                  cognate nouns emphasizing the notion of the verb, (b) I decide, I think (it)
                  good.

judging, judgment, decision, sentence; generally: divine judgment;
                  accusation.

Crispus, ruler of the synagogue at Corinth, converted and baptized by
                  Paul.

criterion; a law-court; a law-case before an arbiter; a cause,
                  controversy.
critical, able to judge or discern.
I knock, beat a door with a stick, to gain admittance.
a cellar, vault, hidden place, crypt.

hidden, secret; as subst: the hidden (secret) things (parts), the
                  inward nature (character).
I am clear as crystal, brilliant like crystal.

(a) I acquire, win, get, purchase, buy, (b) I possess, win mastery
                  over.

a piece of landed property, a field; plur: possessions, property,
                  possibly landed property, property in land.

a beast of burden (generally, a horse or mule) either for riding or for
                  carrying loads on its back, or for yoking to a cart or carriage.
I create, form, shape, make, always of God.

(often of the founding of a city), (a) abstr: creation, (b) concr:
                  creation, creature, institution; always of Divine work, (c) an institution,
                  ordinance.
(often of the founder of a city), creator, God.
(lit: playing with dice, gaming, hence) trickery, sleight.
a steersman, pilot; met: a guide, governor.
in a circle round, round about.
crippled, lame, especially in the hands.
cumin, a plant used as a spice.
a little dog, a house dog.
I bend, stoop down, bow the head.

Cyrene, a district west of Egypt on the Mediterranean coast, forming
                  with Crete a Roman province.
Cyrenius or Quirinius, governor of Syria.
of the Lord, special to the Lord.

(a) abstr: lordship, (b) concr: divine or angelic lordship, domination,
                  dignity, usually with reference to a celestial hierarchy.
I ratify, confirm, make valid, reaffirm, assure.
a dog, universally despised in the East.
a limb, member of a body; fig: a corpse, carcass.
I prevent, debar, hinder; with infin: from doing so and so.

a large village, a city which in constitution has only the status of a
                  village; a country town.
a gnat, mosquito, referred to proverbially as something small.
Cos, an island in the Aegean Sea, south-west of Asia Minor.
Cosam, son of Elmadam and father of Addi.
